user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CloseFileByName:
```c
int32 OS_CloseFileByName(const char *Filename)
{
    int32                        return_code;
    int32                        close_code;
    OS_object_iter_t             iter;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Filename);

    return_code = OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, iter.token);

        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID && (strcmp(stream->stream_name, Filename) == 0))
        {
            /* call OS_close() on the entry referred to by the iterator */
            close_code = OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_FileIteratorClose);

            if (return_code == OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID || close_code != OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                return_code = close_code;
            }
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CloseFileByName:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_FileIteratorClose(osal_id_t filedes, void *arg)
{
    return OS_close(filedes);
}
...
#define OS_FS_ERR_PATH_INVALID (-108)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef int32_t   int32
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the target function and the provided related definitions. There are no occurrences of known compiler-specific language extensions (for example: __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, GCC inline asm, __inline__, __extension__, labels-as-values, or other vendor-specific tokens). The macros shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) expand to standard C constructs (pointer/null check and array indexing/address-of) and the typedef int32 maps to the standard int32_t type. The struct and array declarations, function calls, string compare, and loop constructs are all standard C. If any omitted macro/function definitions (e.g. BUGCHECK or iterator helpers) internally use compiler extensions, those extensions are not visible in the supplied code and so cannot be reported here; based on the provided code fragments themselves, there are no explicit language extensions to flag.
